You're already using a great tool to track your runs! The Garmin Forerunner 245 is an excellent device for monitoring your progress and providing valuable insights to improve your performance.

Improving your pace for a 10K requires a combination of proper training, pacing strategies, and mental preparation. Here are some tips to help you shave off some seconds (or minutes!) from your finish time:

1. **Analyze your Garmin data**: Review your past runs to identify patterns, trends, and areas for improvement. Pay attention to your average pace, cadence, stride length, and heart rate data to understand your strengths and weaknesses.
2. **Incorporate interval training**: Intervals are an effective way to boost your speed and endurance. Try incorporating interval workouts into your training, such as 4-6 x 800m at a fast pace, with active recovery in between. This will help you build speed and endurance.
3. **Incorporate hill sprints**: Hill sprints are a great way to improve your explosive power and speed. Find a route with a gentle hill and sprint up it at maximum effort for 30-90 seconds. Walk or jog back down to recover, and repeat for 3-5 sets.
4. **Focus on proper form and running technique**: Good form and technique can help you run more efficiently and reduce your pace. Focus on maintaining a tall posture, landing midfoot or forefoot, and keeping your arms relaxed and bent at around 90 degrees.
5. **Practice pacing**: Practice running at a consistent pace during your training runs. This will help you develop a sense of pace and teach you how to maintain a steady rhythm during the race.
6. **Incorporate tempo runs**: Tempo runs are longer intervals at a moderate to fast pace. They help you build endurance and teach you how to hold a fast pace for an extended period. Aim for 2-3 tempo runs per week, with a mix of shorter and longer distances.
7. **Incorporate strength training**: Building strength in your core, glutes, and legs can help you maintain good form and generate more power with each stride. Focus on exercises like squats, lunges, deadlifts, and leg press.
8. **Taper and rest**: Make sure to taper your training in the last week leading up to the race. This will allow your body to recover and be fresh for the event.
9. **Visualize and mentally prepare**: Visualize yourself crushing your goal pace and feeling strong throughout the race. Focus on positive self-talk, and remind yourself that you've put in the hard work and are ready for this.
10. **Race strategy**: Develop a race strategy that works for you. This might include starting at a conservative pace, picking up the pace at certain points, or using mental tricks to stay motivated during the final kilometers.

Remember, the key to improving your pace is consistent training, patience, and persistence. Stay focused, stay hydrated, and trust in your training. You've got this!
